Legal_Issue: Whether Sandoz's claims of patent invalidity based on broader claims and bad faith can be struck out
Evidence_Assessment: Relevance of allegations regarding omitted prior art and claim scope
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; Prothonotary's order set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On party seeking to strike pleadings to show allegations are legally untenable
Legal_Rule: Pleadings may be struck if it is 'plain and obvious' that the allegations are legally untenable
Procedural_Issue: Striking out of pleadings by Prothonotary
Grounds_for_Claim: Patent invalidity due to overbroad claims and bad faith omission of prior art
Outcome_on_Merits: Claims not struck; issue to be determined at trial
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Sandoz entitled to present full defense
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of omitted prior art, scope of patent claims
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law, rules of civil procedure
Applicant_Challenge: Sandoz challenging Prothonotary's striking of its invalidity claims
Court_Result: Sandoz retains its counterclaims for patent invalidity
Legal_Rule_Source: Case law on striking pleadings, Federal Courts Rules
Standard_of_Proof: Plain and obvious test for striking pleadings
Defendant_Response: Sandoz asserted patent invalidity as defense
Evidence_Type: Pleadings, patent documentation, prior art references
Remedy_Sought: Preservation of defense and appeal of procedural dismissal
Legal_Provision: Section 43 of the Federal Courts Act, Patent Act provisions
Claimant_Status: Bayer as plaintiff, Sandoz as defendant/counterclaimant
Legal_Provision_Cited: Patent Act, Federal Courts Act, relevant case law
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged legal untenability of invalidity defenses
Applicable_Process: Summary dismissal motion before Prothonotary, de novo appeal
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Continuation of patent infringement litigation with invalidity defense
Governing_Rule: Test for striking pleadings: 'plain and obvious' legal untenability
